headline.main: Troop Buildup, an Aggressive Dragnet and the High Price of Terror
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: AN OVERVIEW: NOV. 28, 2001

lead_paragraph: The buildup of United States forces in Afghanistan is far from over, said their commander, Gen. Tommy R. Franks of the Army. The operative word seemed to be ''more.'' More marines will soon arrive, bringing the total to about 1,000. More makeshift bases will be built as needed around the country. And more attack planes will be sent to Central Asia, with the former Soviet republics of Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan the likely staging areas. ADDING PRESSURE -- The goal, of course, is to deliver a final blow to Osama bin Laden and the remnants of his Taliban shield, believed to have taken refuge near Kandahar in southern Afghanistan and across a stretch of terrain east and south of Kabul, the capital. ''We're going to continue to apply pressure,'' General Franks said.
abstract: Overview of day's events in war on terrorism
